action.action-desc: Ms. Schakowsky (for herself, Ms. DeLauro, Mrs. Dingell, Ms. Norton, Ms. Pingree, Ms. Velázquez, Mrs. Watson Coleman, Mr. Lynch, and Mr. Grijalva) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To amend the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to deem certain substances to be unsafe for use as food contact substances, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the No Toxics in Food Packaging Act of 2023.

section.header: Substances deemed unsafe for use as food contact substances

subsection.text: Section 409 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 348) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subsection.header: Substances deemed unsafe for use as food contact substances

paragraph.text: For purposes of this section and section 402(a)(2)(C), the following are deemed to be unsafe for use as food contact substances:

subparagraph.text: Any chemical belonging to the class of ortho-phthalates.
Any chemical belonging to the class of PFAS.
Bisphenol A, B, S, F, or AF or related compounds.

paragraph.text: In acting in response to any petition under this section to establish safety with respect to a food contact substance that the Secretary determines to be an alternative to a substance listed in paragraph (1), in addition to the criteria under subsection (c), the Secretary shall consider potential adverse effects of exposure to the substance on vulnerable populations.

subparagraph.text: The term ortho-phthalates means a class of chemicals that are esters of ortho-phthalic acid including—
The term PFAS means a perfluoroalkyl substance or a polyfluoroalkyl substance that is man-made with at least 1 fully fluorinated carbon atom.

The term vulnerable population means a human population that is subject to the potential for disproportionate exposure to, or the potential for disproportionate adverse effect from exposure to, a chemical substance or mixture, including—

clause.text: workers who may be exposed to chemical substances and mixtures;
residents in communities subject to disproportionate exposures; and
members of any other appropriate population identified by the Secretary.

subsection.text: Section 409(j) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act, as added by subsection (a), applies beginning on the date that is 2 years after the date of enactment of this Act.
